hedline.hl1: The Kinder Side of a Scorpion Sting

abstract.p: Researchers at University of California at Irvine develop a chemical that works like scorpion venom, and they say it may one day help doctors who perform organ transplants or treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and arthritis; photo (S)

block.p: The only things scorpions inspire in most people are fear and a desire to get out of the way of their poison-tipped stingers.

But researchers at the University of California at Irvine say they have developed a chemical that works like scorpion venom, but instead of harming people, it may one day help doctors who perform organ transplants or treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and arthritis.
The only things scorpions inspire in most people are fear and a desire to get out of the way of their poison-tipped stingers.

But researchers at the University of California at Irvine say they have developed a chemical that works like scorpion venom, but instead of harming people, it may one day help doctors who perform organ transplants or treat autoimmune diseases like lupus and arthritis.
The findings were reported last week in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

The author of the study, Dr. Heike Wulff, a pharmaceutical chemist, said in an interview that the synthetic chemical, TRAM-34, had not been modeled on scorpion venom, but was inspired by discoveries about how the poison affected the cells of scorpion victims.
The venom inactivates some cell functions, including the immune response system, but is not usually fatal.
Likewise, the drugs, like cyclosporin, now given to suppress the immune response in transplant and other patients also have detrimental effects, like gastrointestinal and urinary tract problems.
TRAM-34 appears to be more adept at suppressing T-cells, part of the body's arsenal against foreign objects, without hurting the production of enzymes and other important cellular functions.
Dr. Wulff said the findings were preliminary, and he could not predict when the chemical might be tested on people.
